title: Dieter Aschenborn
text:
Dieter Aschenborn (15 November 1915 in Okahandja, <a href="Namibia">Namibia</a> – September 2002 in <a href="Windhoek">Windhoek</a>, Namibia) was a Namibian painter. He was the son of the <a href="animal%20painter">animal painter</a> <a href="Hans%20Aschenborn">Hans Aschenborn</a>.
Biography.
At the age of six, he moved with his family from Namibia (at that time South West Africa) to <a href="Stellenbosch">Stellenbosch</a> in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> and shortly thereafter to <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. Later Dieter Aschenborn returned to South Africa to work as a farmer. In the second World War he was interned. After the war Aschenborn became the first gamewarden of the <a href="Etosha%20National%20Park">Etosha National Park</a> till 1952. In the park he developed his <a href="leather%20painting">leather painting</a>s which earned him a reputation in southern Africa. He moved to Windhoek and he was able from now on to live entirely from his art.
Aschenborn is especially known as an <a href="animal%20painter">animal painter</a> of <a href="Africa">Africa</a>n <a href="wildlife">wildlife</a>. He made himself also a name with <a href="drawing">drawing</a>s and <a href="sculpture">sculpture</a>s, especially <a href="relief">relief</a>s cut out of <a href="wood">wood</a>, which together with <a href="mural">mural</a>s of his decorate several public buildings in Namibia. He also designed <a href="postage%20stamp">postage stamp</a>s for Namibia. He also painted on leather and parchment.
Dieter's son <a href="Uli%20Aschenborn">Uli Aschenborn</a> is also an artist.
